entry.title: Re: Need guidance on IDOC archive reload process
entry.content: For reloading archived IDocs, you’re right to look at RSEXARCL. It can reload IDocs, but running it in the foreground with high volume isn’t recommended — it may time out or lock resources. For large volumes, it’s safer to use background jobs with proper selection criteria.

entry.title: Re: SAP TRM: Loan Structure set up
entry.content:
1. Loan Product Type – 55A

Loan Product Type 55A is used for standard loan processing. Under this product type:

Principal Inflow represents the loan amount received.
Principal Outflow represents repayments made over time.
Interest is calculated based on the outstanding principal, meaning the system always computes interest on the available (remaining) principal balance.
 

2. Repayment Structure

Repayment terms depend entirely on the agreement negotiated with the bank or financial institution. Common practices include:

Long‑term loans: Typically repaid through installments (monthly, quarterly, semi‑annual, etc.).
Short‑term loans: Often repaid through a single final repayment on the loan maturity date.
Partial repayments: Borrowers may make intermediate partial payments, which reduce the outstanding principal and therefore impact future interest calculations.
 

3. Balance / Exposure

In treasury and banking terminology, the outstanding loan balance is referred to as Exposure.

 

At any point in time:
 

Exposure = Total Principal Inflow - Total Principal  Outflow

This exposure value is used for:
Interest calculation
Reporting (all treasury and loan reports display this balance)

entry.title: SAP CPM/ CPD – Workflow Approval Does Not Finalize Final Planning (Pending → Approved)
entry.content:
I’m working with SAP Commercial Project Management (CPM) and facing an issue with workflow-based Change Request (CR) approval and Final Planning.

Scenario:
When a CR is approved manually via the CPM UI, the Final Planning values (forecast / project overhead) move correctly from Pending to Approved. However, when the same CR is approved via workflow, the CR status changes to Approved and the Update Documents activity is created, but the forecast values remain in Pending.

What I have verified so far:

  • CR status is updated to Approved successfully.

  • /PICM/FM_ISSUE_CR_UPDATE_API is used correctly to update issue root and activities.

  • Update Documents activity is created and persisted (with a real activity ID).

  • BOPF transaction save (/bobf/if_tra_transaction_mgr->save) and lifecycle action (root-clt_crt_next) are executed.

  • No authorization errors, dumps, or messages occur.

  • The same CR finalized manually in the UI immediately updates the forecast.

Observations:

  • Forecast update (Pending → Approved) only happens when Final Planning is saved from the UI.

  • Workflow approval, background execution, SUBMIT reports, or direct BOPF saves do not trigger Final Planning reconciliation.

  • CEAs (Cost Estimation Alternatives) are created but not finalized when approval happens via workflow.

My understanding so far:
Final Planning execution appears to be bound to an active FPM / Analytics planning runtime context, which is only available during UI execution. Workflow approval seems to be governance-only and does not execute Final Planning by design.

Question:
Is there a supported way (BAdI, exit, framework API, or documented pattern) to trigger Final Planning / CEA finalization after workflow approval without manual UI interaction?
If not, what is the recommended SAP-compliant approach to handle workflow-approved CRs so that forecast values are finalized correctly?

Any guidance from someone who has solved this in CPM would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: SAP TRM: Facility Fees on Bilateral Facility 56A
entry.content:
Repayment Frequency Setup
In the Condition Details of the loan transaction, the repayment frequency is maintained in the same way as the interest payment frequency.
- Open the Condition Details screen.
- Navigate to the Repayment section.
- Select the Frequency field.
- Choose the appropriate interval (e.g., Month).
- Enter the frequency factor.
- For quarterly repayment, select Month and enter 3.
- This means the system will schedule repayments every 3 months.

entry.title: Re: Running Finance Facility in TRM
entry.content:
Running Finance (RF) is always a tricky one in SAP TRM because it behaves very differently from a normal loan. You’ve described the core challenge perfectly:
- No principal inflow is credited to the bank account
- The facility is used indirectly (e.g., bank pays vendors on your behalf)
- Interest is charged only on the utilized portion
- Utilization fluctuates daily based on AP payments, bank settlements, etc.
SAP TRM can handle this, but not through standard Interest Rate Instruments alone. RF needs a slightly different modeling approach.
Below is the cleanest, most commonly accepted method used in Saudi banks and corporates.

Recommended Approach: Model RF as a Credit Line + Daily Utilization Postings
1. Create a Credit Line (Facility Limit) in TRM
This represents the approved RF limit from the bank.
- Product Type: 55A (or a custom product type for RF)
- Principal Inflow = Facility Limit
- Principal Outflow = Utilization / Repayments
- Interest = Based on daily utilized balance
But — you do NOT post the inflow to the bank account, because RF is not actually credited.
So mark these Update type not relevant for FI posing 
This gives you:
- Facility limit
- Exposure tracking
- Interest calculation framework

2. Post Daily/Periodic Utilization as Principal Outflows
Whenever the bank pays vendors on your behalf, the bank statement shows:
- Bank pays vendor
- Your RF utilization increases
In TRM, you post this as:
Principal Outflow (Utilization Increase)
- Debit: Vendor
- Credit: RF Liability GL
This increases the exposure in TRM without any cash inflow.
You can automate this via:
- MT940/BAI2 bank statement integration
- FF_5 posting rules
- Custom Z-interface from AP to TRM

3. Post Repayments as Principal Inflows
When you settle the RF with the bank:
- Debit: RF Liability
- Credit: Bank Account
In TRM, this is a Principal Inflow.
This reduces the exposure and future interest.

4. Interest Calculation
TRM will calculate interest based on:
Interest conditions:
- Frequency: Monthly
- Basis: Daily balance
- Rate: As per bank agreement (fixed or floating)
TRM automatically generates:
- Interest accrual
- Interest payment
- Accounting entries

5. Reporting
Once modeled this way, you get full visibility:
- Daily RF exposure
- Available limit
- Utilized amount
- Accrued interest
- Repayment schedule
- Facility aging
This is exactly how treasury departments in KSA handle RF in SAP.

Alternative (Simpler) Approach: Use Money Market Facility (Product Type 550)
Some companies model RF as a revolving MM facility:
- Each utilization = new MM deal
- Each repayment = early termination
- Interest calculated per deal
This works but becomes messy if utilization changes daily.

entry.title: Re: TPM13 ToF Issue
entry.content:
When flows get stuck in ToF (To be Fixed) status in TPM13, it usually means the system has detected an inconsistency between cashflows, position management, and accounting rules. Synchronizing the position alone rarely resolves it — you need to identify why the flows cannot be posted.

Execute Transaction Code: FTR_TRD_ADJUST it will remove inconsistency between tables

Identify the Exact Error Behind the ToF Status
TPM13 only shows the status — not the root cause.
Open the deal in:
- TPM20 → Environment → Error Log
- FTR_EDIT → Environment → Flow Analysis
- TBB1 → Test Run → Error Log
You will usually see one of these technical causes:
- Missing or incorrect account assignment reference (AAR)
- Missing account determination for a specific flow type
- Flow date outside the validity period of the AAR
- Incorrect update type → flow type mapping
- Flow already posted in FI but not updated in TRM
- Flow belongs to a closed period
- Flow is marked as “Fixing Required” due to a valuation mismatch

entry.title: Re: Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure
entry.content:
Thanks for sharing the detailed explanation, Justin.

Based on my experience, using the reset approach is generally more effective because it eliminates the need to run TPM44 at the time of interest payment or receipt. The monthly valuation adjustments are already handled automatically, which keeps the process cleaner and reduces unnecessary steps.

However, the challenge we face is related to posting‑period governance. Since organization only opens the next FI posting period once the new month begins, we are unable to post the actual financial entries for the current month within the same month. For example, January accruals cannot be posted during January; they can only be posted once February is opened. This timing constraint limits our ability to complete the accrual postings in the same period they relate to.

entry.content:
Dear Ktemma

1. Loan Product Type – 55A
Loan Product Type 55A is used for standard loan processing. Under this product type:
- Principal Inflow represents the loan amount received.
- Principal Outflow represents repayments made over time.
- Interest is calculated based on the outstanding principal, meaning the system always computes interest on the available (remaining) principal balance.

2. Repayment Structure
Repayment terms depend entirely on the agreement negotiated with the bank or financial institution. Common practices include:
- Long‑term loans: Typically repaid through installments (monthly, quarterly, semi‑annual, etc.).
- Short‑term loans: Often repaid through a single final repayment on the loan maturity date.
- Partial repayments: Borrowers may make intermediate partial payments, which reduce the outstanding principal and therefore impact future interest calculations.

3. Balance / Exposure
In treasury and banking terminology, the outstanding loan balance is referred to as Exposure.
- At any point in time:
Exposure =Total Principal Inflow-Total Principal Outflow

This exposure value is used for
- Interest calculation
- Reporting (all treasury and loan reports display this balance)

entry.title: Re: Treasury and Risk management trade finance presentati...
entry.content:
For Letters of Credit (85A), SAP hard‑codes the default 21 days as part of the LC master data logic.
This value is not driven by product type, not driven by condition configuration, and not driven by account assignment references.
SAP assumes:
- 21 days is the standard UCP600 presentation period
- Users can overwrite it manually if needed
Because of this, there is no standard SPRO node to change the default from 21 → 15.
This is why you couldn’t find it in customizing — it simply doesn’t exist

Use BAdI:
FTR_TR_GENERIC
or
FTR_TR_TRANSACTION (depending on your S/4HANA version)
Inside the BAdI, you can:
- Detect product type = 85A
- Replace default presentation period = 21 → 15
- Lock the field or leave it editable
This is the cleanest and most common solution.

entry.title: Re: Recovery of amortization in the event of a revaluation
entry.content:
Dear Sidney

Is there a standard TRM transaction to post the one‑time catch‑up amortization?
No — SAP does not provide a dedicated standard transaction for this specific scenario.
SAP TRM assumes that amortization begins from the acquisition date, and it does not offer a lifecycle event to:
- retroactively amortize past periods
- adjust the premium/discount balance as of a changeover date
- post a one‑time catch‑up entry
This is why you cannot trigger this via TPM1, TPM18, TPM44, or any other standard valuation function.

The standard and SAP‑recommended approach is:
A. Post the catch‑up amortization manually in FI
You post the €50,000 amortization adjustment directly in FI:
- Debit: Amortization Expense
- Credit: Bond Premium (or Discount) Adjustment Account
This brings the premium/discount balance to the correct value as of the changeover date.
This manual FI posting is the only correct way to adjust historical amortization.

Adjust the amortized cost in TRM so that future TPM1 runs work correctly
After the manual FI posting, you must ensure that SAP TRM’s position value reflects the new amortized cost basis.
You do this by:
Using TPM20 → Position Adjustment (Write‑Up / Write‑Down)
This allows you to adjust the book value of the bond so that:
- The remaining premium/discount = €50,000
- Future amortization via TPM1 is calculated correctly
- No double‑counting occurs
This is the closest thing SAP offers to a “valuation changeover” function.

After the adjustment, SAP will correctly amortize the remaining €50,000
Once the manual FI posting and position adjustment are done:
- Run TPM1 monthly
- SAP will amortize the remaining €50,000 over the remaining life of the bond
- All future postings will follow the amortized cost principle
- No further manual intervention is needed
This is exactly how SAP expects you to transition from one valuation method to another.

SAP TRM valuation logic is strictly forward‑looking:
- It amortizes from acquisition date
- It does not support retroactive amortization
- It does not allow a “valuation method switch” lifecycle event
- It assumes historical amortization is already correct in the system
Therefore, SAP leaves the catch‑up adjustment to manual FI posting + position adjustment.

Recommended Process for Your Example
Bond purchased at 101% → Premium = €100,000
Amortization from 2020 to 2025 (outside SAP) = €50,000
Remaining premium as of 31‑Dec‑2025 = €50,000
Step 1 — Post €50,000 amortization manually in FI
This aligns the income statement.
Step 2 — Adjust TRM position using TPM20
Bring the amortized cost to the correct value.
Step 3 — From January 2026 onward
Run TPM1 monthly → SAP amortizes the remaining €50,000 automatically.

entry.title: Re: How to fix the warning: Limit Management was not updated
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Public Cloud, Limit Management is always active in the background, even if you don’t explicitly use it. When you introduce a new company code into TRM:

  • The system checks whether this company code is assigned to a Limit Product Group
  • It checks whether Limit Types exist for the product types you are mirroring
  • It checks whether Utilization Categories are defined
  • If nothing is assigned, SAP triggers a warning, not an error

entry.title: Re: Custom Fields Added in TMR1,TM00,TX-3,TPM13 and S_ALR...
entry.content:
TM00 is one of the few TRM reports that reads VTBFHA directly and supports customer enhancements via:
- BAdI FTR_REPORTING
- Enhancement Spot ES_FTR_REPORTING
That’s why your fields appear there.
The other reports (TMR1, TX-3, S_ALR_87015205, TPM13) do not read VTBFHA directly.
They use logical databases, info structures, or valuation layers, which means:

Other Reports uses the logical database FTR.
To add custom fields:
Step 1 — Implement Enhancement
Use enhancement:
FTR_LDB_ADD_FIELDS (or customer include in structure FTR_S_POSITIONS)
Step 2 — Populate the fields
Use user exit:
Inside the exit, read VTBFHA and populate your custom fields.

entry.title: HANA Database Memory Consumption in Secondary is high than Primary
entry.content:
Dear Guru's,

We Have a NetWeaver System running on Hana Database version Hana 2.0 SP 07 on RHEL with HA Setup.
Primary and Secondary has Same hardware setup like Same CPU, Same RAM and Same File System and both Servers are running in AWS.
We are witnessing High Memory Usage in Secondary than Primary where we have RAM about around 250 GB on Primary and Secondary.Primary is using only around 120 GB whereas Secondary Server is utilizing around 160 GB which is higher than Primary.
We recently did a Failover Test where Secondary became Primary and ran for about 15 minutes as Primary and immediately it was rolled back.
Is it because of the Failover RAM has spiked and Memory not reduced since we immediately rolled back ?
I ran the SQL Statements with respect to replication where we will use proxy schema but that does not provide much information.

Could you please help and do the needful on how to found out the cause of Memory Spike in Secondary Server than Primary Server.

We also performed multiple Failover Tests on other systems but this issue we did not had in any of the environment. All Database are running with same version.

Thanks and Regards,
Mithran

entry.title: Re: Administration of Collar FX Option (Product Type 76A)
entry.content:
Dear Andersonm

Not in standard 76A functionality.
And the reason is structural:
SAP treats a Collar as one combined product with:
- A long Put
- A short Call
- A single net premium cash flow at inception
This is why SAP Help explicitly states:
“When you conclude a transaction, the cash flow consists only of the premium.”

SAP assumes the Collar is structured as a zero‑cost collar, or at least a single net premium, not two separate premium legs.
SAP’s 76A design:
- Generates one premium flow only
- Does not create two independent option legs
- Does not allow separate premium settlement dates for each leg
- Does not allow “premium on exercise” for one leg while the other is settled at trade date
This is a deliberate simplification: SAP models the Collar as a single instrument, not two linked options.

Banks typically settle:
- Put premium (paid)
- Call premium (received)
…on trade date, resulting in net zero.
This is a real‑world practice, but SAP’s 76A does not mirror this structure.

Model the Collar as two separate FX options:
- Product type 75A – FX Option (Put)
- Product type 75A – FX Option (Call)
This gives you:
- Two independent premiums
- Two independent cash flows
- Two independent exercise decisions
- Full control over settlement behavior
This is also the approach SAP recommends in consulting notes when banks require separate premium handling.


How to exercise one leg and close the other?
SAP provides three key functions for FX options:
1. Exercise (TPM20)
Use this for the option you want to exercise.
This will:
- Generate the FX settlement
- Post the exercise premium (if applicable)
- Close the exercised leg
2. Closeout / Early Termination (TPM18)
Use this for the option you do not want to exercise.
This will:
- Close the option at zero value (if it expires worthless)
- Post the final valuation adjustment
- Remove it from open positions
3. Automatic Expiry
If you do nothing, SAP will:
- Let the option expire worthless
- Post the final valuation at maturity
But for audit clarity, most treasury teams explicitly close the unexercised leg using TPM18.

Recommended operational process (best practice)
If you use 76A (standard Collar):
- You can exercise the Collar (TPM20)
- But you cannot selectively exercise only one leg
- You cannot post two premiums on trade date
- You cannot post premium on exercise
This does not match your bank’s process.
If you use two 75A options (recommended):
- Create two FX options (Put buy + Call sell)
- Post both premiums on trade date (net zero)
- On settlement date:
- Exercise the in‑the‑money option (TPM20)
- Close the out‑of‑the‑money option (TPM18)
This exactly matches your bank’s lifecycle.

Thanks

entry.title: Re: Step-By-Step Guide to Create SAP Integration Suite Trial Account and Assigning Required Roles
entry.content:
Yes, you can create and manage APIs in the SAP Integration Suite using an SAP BTP trial account.
Go to Security -> Select users -> Click Role Collection ->Click on 3dots ->Select below Roles and Assign Role Collection.

Required Roles:

  • APIManagement.SelfService.Administrator
  • AuthGroup.SelfService.Admin

For more details on other capability roles, please find SAP’s official guide on setting up user access in the Integration Suite. You can find the link below.

https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/configuring-user-access?locale=en…

And then Settings->Runtime->API Management(Activate).

entry.title: Re: SideEffect is not refreshing the criticality icon after bound action call
entry.content:
Hi I think I just came accross this particular problem. after spending days trying to figure it out, the approach I took was to add a criticality property in the Main entity in this case your Books entity. and then during the changeStatus action, you update this as well and then instead of using the criticallity of the Bookstatus itself, you can then remove it and use the status from your main entity. I believe there is a better Approach provided by SAP Team to resolve this but for the lack of current solution been found and so you someone else does not spend all their weekend on this, like I did, this is a full workaround. 

entity Books : cuid, managed {
    status : Association to BookStatus;
    criticality:Integer;

}
  this.on('changeStatus', Books, async (req) => {
const criticality=1 //or 2 or 3 or 5 or 0, depending  on which you want
      const bookId = req.params[0].ID
      const newStatus = req.data.newStatus
      await UPDATE(Books)
        .set({ status_code: newStatus, criticality })
        .where({ ID: bookId })
    })
{
 $Type : 'UI.DataField',
 Value : status_code,
 Criticality : criticality, //MAJOR CHANGE HERE
}

Is it possible to configure SAP PM in such a way that during PM Order creation the system filters or automatically selects the appropriate Task List based on the Maintenance Activity Type, while still using one Order Type?

Which standard SAP objects should be used for this (Maintenance Activity Type, Task List Usage, Order Type settings)?

entry.title: How to Map Android Device Specs to SAC GenericPhone/Generic Tablet/Large Tablet Classification
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

 

I found the Android device specifications for SAC in Help Portal (https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/cde87f49a8eb4c9fabb563cf2ec2b38b.html). However, I’m unsure how to confirm whether my Android device falls into the Generic Tablet/Large Tablet/Generic Phone category, and how to map my device’s actual parameters to the size preview specifications listed in the SAC Help Portal.
 
I've checked the "About My Device" section on multiple mobile devices, but the info displayed there does not seem to directly align with the specifications defined in the Help Portal(768 px/769~1024px/1025px). Also, the specifications in help portal and SAC responsive page (480*853/1024*768/1280*800) look a bit different, and I am also wondering whether there are any differences between them.
 
Are there any specific transformation rules for this mapping process? Or could it be that I’m not checking the correct section on the devices to retrieve the required specifications for confirming the tablet type?
 
 
 
Any tips or insights would be highly appreciated! Thank you in advance!

 

SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: Re: SAP ECC vs S/4HANA Integration Capabilities: A Practical Guide for Integration Architects
entry.content:
Several statements in the post are not accurate and could mislead community members:

  1. OData Exclusivity to S/4HANA: The post claims OData is a "transformative" feature that "S/4HANA has that ECC doesn't", with tables marking it as unavailable in ECC without "workarounds". This is misleading. OData is supported in ECC through SAP NetWeaver Gateway, typically embedded in systems on NetWeaver 7.4 or later. It allows exposure of RFCs, BAPIs, and tables as RESTful services via transaction SEGW, enabling integrations like Fiori or Microsoft Power Platform connections. S/4HANA provides enhancements such as OData V4 and RAP, but Gateway is an official SAP component, not a workaround. This exaggeration creates an artificial gap, potentially discouraging valid ECC-based solutions.
  2. JSON Support as S/4HANA-Exclusive: The "What S/4HANA Adds Over ECC" table lists "No" for JSON in ECC. This is incorrect. ECC's Gateway supports JSON in OData V2 services via query parameters like $format=json, available since Gateway 2.0 (from 2011). JSON is inherent to OData, not an addition in S/4HANA.
  3. Event-Driven Integration Overstated as S/4HANA-Only: The table marks events as "Limited" in ECC and fully available in S/4HANA. ECC supports mechanisms like workflow events, change pointers, and output determination for near-real-time triggers, integrable with external brokers via PI/PO. S/4HANA standardizes business events, but Event Mesh is a BTP cloud service, not native to on-premises S/4HANA. This conflates on-prem and cloud, understating ECC's extensibility.
  4. SOAP Misrepresentation in ECC: Section 2.3 states ECC exposes SOAP services "using the Enterprise Services Repository (ESR)." ESR is part of PI/PO middleware, not ECC. Native SOAP exposure occurs via SOAMANAGER for ABAP services, without ESR for basic setups. 
  5. Protocol Matrix Inaccuracies: OData is marked "No" for ECC  and contradics the article's acknowledgment of Gateway. Events are similarly binary, and file interfaces are rated "Low" performance despite efficiency for batch use. 
  6. Cloud vs. On-Premises Inconsistency: The title focuses on "On-Premises systems," yet examples rely exclusively on cloud tools like CPI, BTP, and Event Mesh. On-premises alternatives (e.g., direct RFC/IDoc or PI/PO) are ignored, biasing toward SAP's cloud offerings.
  7. Additional Minor Issues:
    • BAPI characteristics note "Type-safe" parameters, but IDocs also feature typed segments.
    • IDoc table lists some types as "Outbound" only (e.g., INVOIC02), overlooking bidirectional support.
    • OData avoidance for bulk transfers overlooks batching capabilities.
    • API Business Hub is presented as an S/4HANA advantage, but it includes ECC APIs via Gateway.
    • Checklists downplay Gateway as a workaround while omitting its setup details.

Overall, the post is not very accurate and not a balanced guide. Architects should consult official SAP documentation for accurate information.

entry.title: A Wish for CLI-Based ABAP
entry.content:
A Wish for CLI-Based ABAP

Why modern SAP development needs to move closer to the terminal

Lately I’ve been thinking a lot about where SAP development is heading — and where it feels like it isn’t.

Outside the SAP ecosystem, development has moved decisively toward text-based, terminal-driven workflows. Code lives in Git, workflows start in the CLI, automation is the default, and AI tools increasingly operate directly on source files.

Inside the SAP world, especially around extensibility, we often see the opposite: GUI-driven tools, browser-based editors, and logic that gets generated somewhere behind the scenes.

After working hands-on with extensibility in S/4HANA recently, that contrast became impossible to ignore. It led to a simple but persistent thought:

What if ABAP fully embraced a CLI-based, developer-centric development model?

Modern development has moved to the terminal

For many developers today, the terminal isn’t a niche preference — it’s the center of gravity.

Modern development typically means:

  • source code as plain text

  • Git as the system of record

  • the terminal as the control plane

  • automation and pipelines by default

  • AI tools working directly on repositories

Tools like Claude Code make this very tangible. You can sit in a terminal, point the AI at a repository, ask it to explain a codebase, refactor a module, or generate a patch — all as diffs against real files. No wizards, no GUIs — just text in, text out.

Once you get used to working this way, it’s hard not to expect the same experience everywhere.

ABAP lives in a different world

ABAP, by contrast, still revolves around the SAP system itself.

  • Code primarily lives in the database

  • The system is the source of truth

  • Changes move via transports

  • Git integration is optional, secondary, and often awkward

  • Development assumes a running backend, not a repository

Even tools like abapGit, as valuable as they are, don’t change this fundamental model. They bridge worlds — they don’t redefine which world ABAP belongs to.

This means ABAP is not Git-centric. It’s not repository-centric. And as a result, it doesn’t naturally fit into modern CLI-based or AI-assisted workflows.

Low-code doesn’t fix this — it exposes it

SAP’s clean-core strategy has pushed heavily toward Key User Extensibility:

  • Custom Fields

  • Custom Logic

  • Adapt UI

  • GUI-driven configuration with generated artifacts

From a governance and upgrade perspective, this makes sense.

From a developer perspective, it often highlights the core problem.

Custom Logic is still ABAP — typed, structured, technical — but:

  • written in browser editors

  • without proper refactoring or navigation

  • without native Git ownership

  • without automation-friendly workflows

It ends up in an awkward middle ground:

  • too restrictive for developers

  • too complex for actual key users

Low-code doesn’t remove the need for strong developer workflows. It makes the absence of them more visible.

Clean core needs better developer ergonomics, not less code

Clean core is the right goal. There’s no debate there.

But clean core should not mean:

  • hiding code from developers

  • forcing logic into GUIs

  • discouraging automation

  • accepting weaker tooling

In practice, clean core works best with:

  • explicit, text-based code

  • strong testability

  • traceability through Git

  • automation and CI/CD

All of that aligns far better with CLI-friendly, developer-centric workflows than with click-driven configuration.

“CLI-based ABAP” is shorthand for a deeper change

When developers ask for CLI-based ABAP, they’re not chasing trends. And looking at how CAP is designed, SAP also knows this.

They’re really asking for:

  • ABAP source as first-class text

  • Git as a native concept, not a side channel

  • syntax checks, ATC, and tests callable from automation

  • workflows that don’t require a GUI or heavy IDE

  • AI tools that can reason about ABAP like any other language

This doesn’t mean pretending SAP systems aren’t special.
It means acknowledging that system-centric development no longer scales.

Why VS Code actually matters

This is why SAP’s move toward VS Code support for ABAP is so interesting.

VS Code isn’t just another editor. It sits at the center of:

  • Git-first workflows

  • terminals

  • automation

  • AI-assisted development

If ABAP can genuinely move closer to that ecosystem — even gradually — a lot suddenly becomes possible:

  • real CI/CD

  • better collaboration

  • meaningful automation

  • AI tools that work with ABAP, not around it

VS Code isn’t the goal.
It’s a signal.

entry.title: Re: How to make standard Fiori apps open an extended Fior...
entry.content:
Hi @EdsonBravo93

I can see that you want to use same Semantic Object - Action with standard, you need to add a parameter named sap-priority and set the value to 1.

With this parameter you added to target mapping; if you give the users catalog including this target mapping by a role, even the user tries to open the standard application, your target mapping will override it. sap-priority = 1 means if user has this target mapping and the standard one, bring the priority target mapping.

Best Regards.

entry.title: Where are stored the SAPUI5 Debug Sources in the ABAP stack?
entry.content:
In my system S/4HANA 2023 FPS 01 ON-PREMISE, when I debug the Javascript part of a standard SAPUI5 application directly in the Web browser (Dev Tools), I don't want to work with the default minimized "xxxxxx.js" Javascript file (no line feeds, minimized variable names, no comment), I'm using the debug source file "xxxxxx-dbg.js" (via Ctrl+Shift+Alt+P > Select specific modules / Youtube video: Debug UI5 Application Smartly | UI5 Diagnostics Tool (2021)).

I know that the minimized files are stored in the "SAPUI5 ABAP repository" (SAP GUI transaction SE80 > BSP application), under the BSP application whose name is the SAPUI5 application name of the Fiori application. It's a fake BSP application, it's just used to store the SAPUI5 files. For instance, the Fiori app F0859 corresponds to the SAPUI5 application MM_SUPPIV_MANS1 (as shown in the SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library > Implementation information > Configuration > SAPUI5 Application), SE80 shows the minimized files, e.g. utils/QuantityFormatter.js:

For my information, where are stored the debug source files, e.g. where is utils/QuantityFormatter-dbg.js? (the original source files, containing line feeds, original function and variable names, comments)

Thank you.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: Where are stored the SAPUI5 Debug Sources in the ABAP stack?
entry.content:
The debug sources are stored at the root of the BSP application with a technical name starting with "UI5". The correspondance between the real name and the technical name is stored in the file UI5RepositoryPathMapping.xml at the root of the BSP application. Here is the correspondance for utils/QuantityFormatter-dbg.js:

Code of UI5E134F618C9A8E7E08C76004F3EF0E4367209D406 (alias utils/QuantityFormatter-dbg.js):

For information, the code in the red box above corresponds to the below part of the minified source code ("D" corresponds to iDecimal, "f" corresponds to _oQuantityModel, etc.):

Note that the SAPUI5 Javascript SAP notes always deliver both the minified and debug sources e.g. 3680459 - F0859: Fiori app freezes after posting parked Supplier Invoice - SAP for Me. Here, UI55E0142F8D06AD51E1D4479D03C87000C32CFEBD2 is the debug source of the minified source SHAREUTIL.JS:

The content of this note also shows that the UI5* files don't always contain the debug source of a minified version, here component-preload.js is a minified version, and that the source files are not always minified (the TS TypeScript file). NB: I marked the two source files Component-h2-preload.js as minified, although they are technically not, because the debug source is almost as unreadable as the minified version...

For information, the explanation about UI5RepositoryPathMapping.xml was also given here: Solved: when using vs code to deploy Fiori to on premise, ... - SAP Community.

entry.title: Transfer of medical instruments and implants in Medical device Industry using S/4 HANA
entry.content:
Introduction:  

This blog outlines the leading medical device industry business process steps to Transfer medical instruments and implants needed in a surgery from one branch to another branch and provide visibility, tracking, and logistic support to the business process using S4 HANA

In the field instruments and implants can be physically transferred from branch to another branch based on demand and utilization, this process needs to accurately be captured in the SAP system.

When a request is received for transfer of instrument and implants between branches (consignees), from Branch A to Branch B, The SAP data model requires the execution of two transactions; first, a Consignment Pickup Order that pulls the product back to warehouse stock in the “plant of origin” and purpose-built “transfer storage location” not visible to ATP from Branch A and immediately transfer to Branch B with transfer-specific Consignment Fill Order that moves the product to the new branch.

Pre-requisite:

  • The goods requested for transfer are consigned in the system against branch A
  • Virtual storage location set up in S4 to move stock between the rep and not visible to ATP
  • Hospitals and branches must be set up as customers
  • Instruments and Consumables set up separate materials.

Setup Steps:

Configure new consignment document type: -

Step 1: Define Consignment fill up and pick up document types

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document header – Define sales document type.

Consignment Pick up – To pick up inventory from branch A back to the warehouse and virtual storage location

Consignment Fill up. – To deliver inventory to sales rep B

Step 2: Define item categories.

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document item – Define item categories

Consignment pick-up item category

Consignment Fill-up Item category.

Step 3: Schedule lines

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Schedule lines – Define schedule lines.

Consignment Pickup Schedule line.


Consignment Fill up the schedule line

Step 4: Assign document type to the sales area.

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document header – Assign Sales Area to Sales Document Types

Step 5: Assign Item Categories

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document item - Assign Item Categories

Step 6: Assign Schedule Line Categories

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Schedule lines - Assign Schedule Line Categories

Process steps: -

Step 1: - Create pick up order (KA) To pick up inventory from branch A

 


Step 2: Create Inbound delivery and receive goods in the warehouse of origin and virtual storage location.


Step 3. Create a Consignment fill up (KB) order transfer/deliver goods to branch B


Step 4: Create an outbound delivery with reference to the KB Order. Pick, pack, and Issue from the virtual storage location to rep B

Step 5: Asset updated with the new functional location

Conclusion:

  • After going through the above blog, the user should have learned how to transfer goods from one branch to another using S4 HANA
  • Please provide your feedback/comments. You can ask Question / Answer for the open Questions in the SAP Community here

Reference:

 SAP Help Portal

Authors: Mohan Kaliyamoorthy and Immanuel Godwin Johnson

entry.title: Fulfillment of Trial request to the field in Medical Device Industry using S/4 HANA
entry.content:
Introduction:  

This blog outlines the leading industry business process steps to fulfill and track customer request for trials in the field providing visibility to all stakeholders.

It is common practice in the medical industry for customers to request trial of new or modified products to determine effectiveness before placing orders.

The trial products sent out from the warehouse to field must be tracked and stored appropriately when returned as these can be used across customers and geographies. This document details the fulfillment of trial products


Pre-requisite:

  • Hospitals must be set up as customers and sales representatives as employees
  • Instruments and Consumables set up separate materials
  • Dedicated storage locations inside warehouses to store trial products
  1. Process Steps for Trial

 

Setup Steps:

Configure new consignment document type: -

Step 1: Define Consignment fill up and pick up document types

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document header – Define sales document type.

Consignment Fill up. – To deliver trial inventory to customer


Consignment Pick up – To pick up inventory back to warehouse and dedicated storage location after trial


Step 2: Define item categories.

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document item – Define item categories

Consignment Fill-up Item category.

 

Consignment pick-up item category

Step 3: Schedule lines

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Schedule lines – Define schedule lines.

Consignment Fill up the schedule line

 


Consignment Pickup Schedule line.


Step 4: Assign document type to the sales area.

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document header – Assign Sales Area to Sales Document Types

Step 5: Assign Item Categories

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document item - Assign Item Categories

Step 6: Assign Schedule Line Categories

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Schedule lines - Assign Schedule Line Categories

Process steps: -
Step 1. Create a Consignment fill up (KB) order send goods on trial from dedicated trial storage location


Step 2: Create an outbound delivery with reference to the KB Order. Pick, pack, and Issue from the virtual storage location to rep B

Step 4: Asset updated with the new functional location. Equipment identified as trial

Step 5: - Create pick up order (KA) To pick up inventory from customer location after trial


Step 2: Create Inbound delivery and receive goods in the warehouse of origin and virtual storage location.

 


Conclusion:

  • After going through the above blog, the user should have learned how to fulfill a customer request for trial of products using S4 HANA
  • Please provide your feedback/comments. You can ask Question / Answer for the open Questions in the SAP Community here

Reference:

 SAP Help Portal

Authors: Mohan Kaliyamoorthy and Immanuel Godwin Johnson

entry.title: Re: Header Condition in RFQ & Quotation - SAP Public Clou...
entry.content:
Hi, 

 

In Fiori App Manage RFQ you maintain the "Total Value" 

If you would like the price to be updated in other Purchasing documents you can select "Info Record Update", then the price will be updated in Purchasing Information Record. 

In the Fiori App "Manage Supplier Quotation" you maintain the price in the field "Net Order price" and additionally you can select "Info Record Update", so the price will be updated in other Purchasing documents.



The Manage RFQs and Manage Supplier Quotations apps focus on basic pricing fields only, not the full condition technique (pricing procedure).

 

Best regards, 

Elena P.

entry.title: Re: Clarification on Differences Between SAP S/4HANA Clou...
entry.content:
Hi,

Cloud test, demo, and development for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition – three-system landscape

Is a non-productive partner environment with three separate systems:

  • Development
  • Test
  • Production
    (For demonstration, development, and advanced lifecycle tasks.)

More information:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/aa60b129af7b4ce8ae052618c8315d29.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com&locale=en-US

Use case: Suited for full implementation projects and lifecycle management

 

Cloud test, demo, and development for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition – one-system landscape

Is a non-productive partner environment with one system (often with two tenants inside it) that is used for test, demo, and development tasks. You cannot transport content.

Use case: Primarily for demos, partner enablement, key-user testing

 

Choose Three-System Landscape if:

  • You need separate development, test, and production environments. 
  • You’re doing actual SAP implementation projects with formal transports. 
  • You need data refreshes, regression testing, or full lifecycle support. 

Choose One-System Landscape if:

  • You need a simple demo / test / dev environment. 
  • Use for partner enablement or basic demonstration. 
  • You don’t need advanced transport or multiple environment separation.

 

At the link you can see the FAQ about Public Cloud Demo

https://www.sap.com/products/erp/s4hana/trial.html

 

All the best, 

Elena P.

entry.title: Settlement Rule Configuration Issue for Overhead Project (1NT Test Script) - Receiver Category PSG N
entry.content:
Title: Settlement Rule Configuration Issue for Overhead Project (1NT Test Script) - Receiver Category PSG Not Allowed

Hello SAP Community,

I am currently working through the 1NT test script for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition and encountered an issue with settlement rule configuration for an overhead project.

**Situation:**
- Following the 1NT test script section "1.1 Register Project"
- Project created successfully with Project Profile: "Overhead Project (間接費プロジェクト)"
- Settlement Profile assigned: YPSOVH (PS Settlement Overhead Project)

**Issue:**
When attempting to update the settlement rule with Receiver Category "PSG" (Profitability Segment) as instructed in the test script, I receive the following error:

> "Receiver categ. PSG is not allowed by settlement prof. YPSOVH for this"

**Configuration Check (Activity 105768):**
- In settlement profile YPSOVH, the "Profit. Segment" receiver category is set to "Settlement Not Allowed" and appears grayed out (cannot be changed)
- Other receiver categories like G/L Account, Cost Center, and WBS Element are set to "Settlement Optional"

**Questions:**
1. Is PSG (Profitability Segment) typically not allowed as a receiver for overhead projects?
2. Should the test script be using a different receiver category for overhead projects?
3. If PSG should be allowed, what configuration steps am I missing to enable it?
4. How should I proceed with the 1NT test script in this situation?

**Test Script Reference:**
The test script states:
> "Update settlement rule for project (applicable only for projects with revenue)
> Category: PSG"

This makes me wonder if the test script example using "overhead project" is appropriate for PSG settlement, or if there's a configuration prerequisite I'm missing.

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!

**Environment:** SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition
**Configuration Activity:** 105768
**Settlement Profile:** YPSOVH

entry.title: Comment Directly on User Guide for SAP Green Ledger
entry.content:
We’re excited to introduce external commenting for SAP Green Ledger User Guide on SAP Help Portal!

You can now leave comments directly on User Guide for SAP Green Ledger to share feedback, ask questions, or suggest improvements, right where you’re reading. This helps us improve the guide together by capturing your feedback in context and continuously refining the documentation to better support your daily work with SAP Green Ledger.

For more information about documentation feedback on SAP Help Portal, see Giving Documentation Feedback on SAP Help Portal | SAP Help Portal.

At the moment, commenting is only available for the User Guide. It is not yet supported for Integration Guide or Admin Guide. That said, we’d absolutely love to hear your advice and collect more feedback.

We truly appreciate your time, insights, and support as we work together to make SAP Green Ledger documentation even better!

entry.title: Purchasing of Fixed Assets
entry.content:
Hi, 

I am trying to process fixed asset through procurement. My requirement is to have different cost centers in my FA master data and in transactional level, Purchase Order/ Purchase Requisition. I created a custom account assignment and made the cost center and fixed asset fields mandatory. I created fixed asset master data with Cost Center CC1000. Now, during creation of purchase order, I would want to charge the fixed asset to cost center CC2000. But when i try to enter and save the document, the cost center would automatically change to CC1000. 

Is changing cost center not standard/allowed in S4Hana Public? I want the cost centers to be different because:

1. Master data cost center - for depreciation
2. Purchase Order cost center - where cost/budget would come from 


Is there a workaround to cater having cost centers in master data and during transactions?

entry.title: How to find the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting (ID: F3172) ?
entry.content:
The app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting (ID: F3172) is not visible in the Fiori Launchpad search.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to find the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Report...
entry.content:
Firstly, the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting is integrated as an add-on feature within the app Run Statutory Reports. Consequently, it does not possess its own dedicated Fiori tile, which leads to its absence in the Fiori Launchpad search.

Secondly, to locate the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting within the app Run Statutory Reports, the following requirements must be met: 

  1. Since the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting is a licensed feature of DRC - Statutory Reporting, activating scope item 5XU is necessary.
  2. Activation of this feature for the relevant country is required through the configuration activity Activate Document and Reporting Compliance Features (ID: 105518).
  3. After activation, updating the reporting task is necessary in the app Run Statutory Reports.

3704701 - How to find the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting (ID: F3172) ? - SAP for Me

entry.title: 销售高级首付款申请
entry.content:
业务背景

标准首付款业务场景BKJ在结算时会有舍入差异的问题，公有云2602版本升级后通过高级首付款场景可以解决此痛点需求。

前提配置

本博文案例基于中国台湾版本展示方案，为了满足中国台湾电子发票打印，需要做一些前提配置。

1.配置点102187：Assign eDocument Type to Invoice Verification Transaction

2.配置点 105518: Activate Document and Reporting Compliance Features

3. 配置点106596:  Define Business Places for Taiwan

4. 配置点102411:  Assign Number Ranges to Business Places for Official Doc. Numbering MENA

5. 主数据维护业务伙伴：

系统实现

如果使用标准BKJ首付款场景，最终发票在发票界面里税额会有舍入误差如下：

首付款金额300的总税应该是15，而发票界面是8+8=16。尽管财务凭证的税额是正确的，但是中国台湾电子发票系统集成的是公有云发票，所以导致电子发票数据出错。

以下通过高级首付款申请来解决此舍入差异痛点

1.APP:创建销售订单，建立两条行项目。分别对两个行项目进入行项目细节，开票页签，选择首付款申请：

设定金额300/PC

转到抬头销售页面，输入销售办公室和销售组

转到抬头开票计划页签，输入首付款，注意开票类型是DPR1。

总金额600的50%=300.

然后保存订单。

2.APP：创建临时开票凭证(create preliminary billing document)，选择销售订单进行创建，对首付款创建临时开票。

通过APP:管理临时开票凭证，可以查看细节，税务为7+8=15正确。

3.对首付款创建开票凭证，APP: 管理临时开票凭证。选择临时开票凭证，然后点击创建开票凭证。

查看开票凭证和财务凭证：

4.APP：过账收款（Post incoming payment）生成日记账分录。过账后销售订单中计划行里的锁会自动解开。查看日记账分录：

5.创建交货单，拣配，过账发货。

6.APP：创建开票凭证, 选择交货单进行开票，点击行项目查看价格细节：

查看开票凭证和财务凭证：

查看发票打印：

7.APP：EDocument 主控室，生成电子发票并且下载XML。

感谢观看

entry.title: Re: Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure
entry.content:
@mezeshan Thank you very much for the valuable comments. 

This blog post was intended to explain the fundamental principles and key differences between the reset and difference procedures. While each method has its pros and cons, a detailed analysis of selection criteria is not elaborated on herein (this can be expanded in subsequent updates).

Based on our experience with TRM implementations across multiple countries, the choice between these two procedures is largely dependent on the accounting practices and preferences applicable to a specific country or personal habit. A significant number of users opt for the reset procedure primarily to align with the valuation method adopted in SAP FI-GL (e.g., FX valuation for monetary items). Another key factor is system constraints—as you noted, the reset procedure requires the subsequent accounting period to have been opened in advance, or TPM44 for the to-be-closed period may need to be executed later.

Notably, the difference procedure does not necessarily mandate the execution of TPM44 at the time of interest payments, unless there is a requirement to ensure the accuracy of accrual balances and interest income/expenses on/up to the exact date of interest payments. Some users choose the difference procedure for additional reasons, such as the need for more frequent accruals (even on a daily basis)—in such cases, they prefer to track the incremental amount of each accrual rather than seeing frequent resets, or they need to perform FX rate corrections on prior-period accruals.

entry.title: Re: ASSET RETIREMENT OBLIGATION IN SAP S/4 HANA
entry.content: Yes, SAP does a good job documenting how to use LSMW and even delivers a pretty good template definition.  It uses a BADI which also does a good job of managing the data though it's a bit complex and quite long; a single ARO obligation could potentially take up to 1,000 rows of data.  To alleviate this, they have also delivered a new solution in S/4HANA but that was before they discontinued the solution.

entry.title: SAP BTP AI Best Practices: From Strategy to Implementation
entry.content:
In this live YouTube session, discover how SAP BTP AI Best Practices help turn AI ambition into production-ready enterprise solutions. This curated set of guides and patterns provides both a functional view of what AI can deliver for business scenarios and a technical view of how to implement it effectively on SAP Business Technology Platform.

 

We’ll explain why these best practices matter, walk through the underlying taxonomy that brings structure and clarity to AI use cases, and give an overview of the most relevant patterns you can apply directly in your projects. Join us to learn how to design, build, and scale AI solutions on SAP BTP with confidence, consistency, and real business impact.

Register: https://events.sap.com/sap-btp-2025/en_us/home.html

entry.title: Re: Extending SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 Using CAP
entry.content:
Hi @Quablab ,

using @opentype declarations in a CAPM service definition allows your service to accept new fields or structures added later, without breaking consumers.

service opportunityEnhancement @(path: '/opportunityExtension/api/v1') {
@open

type object {};
action opportunityUpdate(entity : String,
                                                  beforeImage : object,
                                                 currentImage : object,
                                                 context : object,
                                                 userId : String,
                                                skipValidations : Boolean,
                                               isDryRun : Boolean,
                                              employeeId : String) returns object;

}

}
